text: I feel very left out for not enjoying this book… The first 200 pages are about these territory wars between kids that make little to no sense. This isn’t really the main plotline so I have no idea why this was such a huge part of the novel. The last two hundred pages get better in that you get some answers about Taylor’s past and family, but you figure it out on your own and then you still have another 100+ pages to get through. Like this book won the Printz award in 2009? Maybe I would have enjoyed it more if I read it back then/when I was younger.

After reading so many positive reviews, I bought this for my teenaged granddaughter and only then read it. I should have read it first. The first half of the book was so hard to follow, I would have set it aside had I not been determined to see if it lived up to the glowing reviews. The story has real potential, but the execution is rambling. The story is nearly unrelentingly dark, but a dark novel with a compelling, well-told story is worth the journey. This one left me with a bad taste and a sense of wasted reading hours. What I like about it is that the book attracts avid fans. So one day I will look forward to a conversation with my granddaughter about it. Her perspective may make me decide to re-read it, with new eyes.

Just kinda meh. Confusing introduction where I wasn’t sure what was real and what was a dream she had. I didn’t feel a strong connection to anyone either, unfortunately. The terf war was also confusing. A lot of it didn’t make sense set up wise until over 100 pages in. Would have enjoyed a better, clear picture of the setting and characters to like it more.

I can see why people love this book BUT it wasn’t for me- I didn’t click with any characters, and it seemed to drag on for a LONG time.I will say that once the twists and story lines start to make sense to the reader, it becomes a lot better to read - but would I read it again? Probably not.ALSO, it did make me cry for the last couple of pages, so there’s that.I generally just didn’t enjoy the writing style- I feel like the plot is good, and if it was written differently with the same plot and twists, I would like it a lot better.

These kids have gone through way serious shit that have been swept under the rug. One admittedly goes to a counsellor which is a good thing, but for the love of all things sacred, let the other characters have therapy too. The amount of trauma that they have endured should not be so easily solved by Love and Friendship anymore. Brownie points for shedding light on teen trauma, minus points for the cheesy execution.This thing isnt going to fly if it was published in the 2020s.

I haven’t read a book this quickly in a while. Fantastic book with a chaotic, yet interesting plot. I cried all the way through. I’m only giving it two stars rather than five, because of the constant racist remarks throughout the book. They made me extremely uncomfortable, and quite frankly they were just unnecessary. This book was written in the early 2000’s…so we definitely can’t blame it on the time and place in history. Perhaps the author is a racist?

I appreciate the opportunity to explore older Australian YA, which has a very different tone and focus than what we anticipate in YA lit today. This novel, however, did not work for present-me - though I'll admit it probably would have been my jam if I had read it when it came out in 2006. The timeline/narrative shifts were confusing and even when these stories converged, I found my interest waning. I always appreciate the discussion that comes with book club but not my favorite pick.

The first 30-50% is just hard to follow until more information is revealed. It’s got a lot of melodrama and definitely feels targeted towards teens, so I rolled my eyes a lot as an adult. I don’t know, maybe the author hit the sweet spot for brain development, but I found it a little insipid.
gosto do enredo mas a forma como esse ele livro é construído é estranhissima

Believe me, I tried to like this book, but the lackluster and predictable story made it so difficult. I actually only finished this because I already DNFed two books. It had its good moments, I particularly loved the narrative about the five kids and would've liked it better if the book was actually about them instead lol (it was one of the very few things that pushed me to keep reading this book). I appreciate the good writing and the development of the characters (especially the female MC whose name I already forgot and don't even wanna bother to look up). Also, why do a lot of people like Jonah Griggs so much? Did I miss something?
I could not get into this story.If you enjoyed it, I am glad. Please continue to support his authors' works.

Por fin acabé este libro y no me ha gustado.He llevado una gran decepción porque todo el mundo lo ponía por las nubes y era el libro favorito de muchos booktubers y sin embargo a mi me ha dejado con una cara un poco extraña al llegar a la última página.Para empezar, no entendía nada de lo que estaba sucediendo en la historia hasta prácticamente más de la mitad del libro. Entonces...¿Qué sentido tiene que todos contaran que su final era increíble si la primera mitad, que son unas 200 páginas, no te enteras ni de quién es la protagonista, quienes son los demás personajes y dónde se encuentran?.Se me hacía tan tedioso leer un libro que no comprendía nada de lo que estaba pasando...Pienso que está mal escrito y que eso hace que no me enterase de nada, además hay millones de personajes y al cuando aparece el nombre de uno, me quedaba tipo "¿y este quién era?".También, la historia de amor pasó de ser de un te odio a un te quiero en un día... Osea nada creíble.Y el final, pues tampoco fue para tanto si el libro no lo estaba entendiendo. Si hubiera estado mejor escrito y me hubiera ubicado mejor en la historia, ese final hubiese estado mejor y me hubiera encantado el libro.Además, no podría hablar de la trama con un hilo argumental y decir "primero pasa esto, luego lo otro y por último aquello" ¡Es imposible! Es todo demasiado confuso.Lo único bueno, fueron las frases bonitas y que el final de algún capítulo me dejaba impactada. Pero sin más. Me hubiera impresionado muchísimo más si estuviera mejor narrado.

فکر می کنم وقتشه که بپذیرم برای این سبک کتاب ها زیادی بزرگ شدم. این کتاب قرار بود استراحت بین کتاب های سنگینم باشه، ولی بیشتر باعث عذابم شدتیلور دختریه که در یک مدرسه شبانه روزی زندگی می کنه و چیز زیادی از گذشته و پدر و مادرش نمی دونه. سال هاست که جنگ های مرزی بین این مدرسه، پسران دانشکده افسری و بچه های شهر در حال انجامه و امسال تیلور نماینده مدرسه خودشه. در طول این جنگ که در واقع یک جور بازی خشنه و با غیبت ناگهانی یکی از مهم ترین افراد زندگیش همزمان شده، تیلور کم کم گذشته اش رو کشف می کنه و تکه های پازل رو کنار هم می چینهریویوهای این کتاب از کسانی که سال هاست نظراتشون رو می خونم، اونقدر خوب بودن که این کتاب چند سال توی لیستم بود و تقریبا مطمئن بودم با یک داستان خیلی جالب مواجه می شم. یک سوم اول کتاب رو هم نخونده بودم که فهمیدم سخت در اشتباهم. داستان برای من به شدت کند پیش می رفت، هیچکدام از وقایع جذاب در واقع هیجان انگیز نبود و راستش... هیچ اهمیتی به تیلور و تلاشش برای کشف گذشته اش نمی دادمدر واقع ستاره دوم فقط به خاطر اینه که در انتها به نظرم اومد واقعا داستانی وجود داشت که البته برای من جالب نبود. ریویو نوشتن برای کتاب های دو و سه ستاره خیلی سخته، نه اونقدر ازشون متنفرم که یک ریویو پرشور منفی بنویسم، نه اونقدر دوسشون دارم که بررسیشون کنمخلاصه که "در جاده جلیکو"، ممنونم که برای ریویو نوشتن هم رفتی رو اعصابم٩٩.١١.٢٨
Very confusing

Reseña completa: https://www.lectorfisgon.com/resena-c...RESUMENLa verdad es que tengo sentimientos encontrados con esta novela, con cosas que sí me han gustado y otras tantas que me han parecido demasiado incoherentes o poco desarrolladas. Hasta las 100 primeras páginas, todo es muy confuso. Hay muchísimos interrogantes y hechos que no sabes por qué están sucediendo. La verdad que todo me parecía caótico y desordenado, e incluso me aburría avanzar en la historia porque sentía que no iba a ningún sitio. Sin embargo, a partir de la mitad del libro conseguí engancharme bastante gracias a que hay más acción y se desarrolla el arco romántico. Aunque «En el camino de Jellicoe» parece contener muchas tramas por donde tirar: guerras territoriales, una desaparición, hechos que ocurrieron en el pasado, etc. La verdad es que finalmente la acción se centra casi por completo en nuestra protagonista Taylor y su pasado.Las guerras territoriales, que se van anunciado a lo bombo y platillo por todo el libro, brillan su ausencia (y lógica). Sinceramente, da la impresión que nadie tiene un motivo serio para nada. Los personajes atacan los otros bandos porque sí y se perdonan con una celeridad pasmante🤦‍♀️🤦‍♀️.En cuanto los hechos del pasado, vale la pena mencionar que son complejos y tristes, además de contarnos sobre nuevas esperanzas y otras rotas♥. Sin duda, esta línea argumental es la que más interesante me ha parecido de toda la novela y descubrir cómo se conectaría con la historia del presente.Sobre los personajes, reconozco que no he acabado de conectar con Taylor, nuestra protagonista. Al inicio de la novela me pareció que tenía potencial, pero varias cosas de ella las encontré demasiado inmaduras y, en general, me pareció un personaje plano. Por el contrario, me he dado cuenta de que el resto de personajes de En el camino de Jellicoe sí que me gustado bastante. «En el camino de Jellicoe» es una novela que descubre pasados rotos y complejos, pero con una protagonista que, en mi opinión, no consigue estar a la altura. Además, aunque a partir de la mitad del libro disfruté la historia, el final se me quedó algo flojo.

Es un young adult de una historia contada a dos tiempos sobre vínculos familiares con un transfondo bonito y emotivo. Pero a mí me ha faltado algo... No entendía nada hasta la página 300 aprox, qué hacían realmente esos personajes, quiénes eran, por qué eran así... Me sentí muy perdida durante demasiado tiempo con muchas piezas sueltas pendientes de encajar. Hay mucha intriga y eso es un aspecto guay de esta lectura.Luego todo empieza a encajar. Todo. Y es como que empieza a molar porque por fin vas entendiendo todo. Pero a pesar de esto y a pesar de que la última parte gana muchos puntos, no conseguí conectar con la historia. Ya digo, no me caló. Y creo que es por haberme tenido perdida durante demasiadas páginas para mi gusto, y por la protagonista... Esa protagonista es que no. No. Hubiera agradecido un poco más de guía al lector, algun dato en ciertas partes del texto... y una prota con más carisma.Pero oye, la historia, original, es. Yo sé que este libro ha gustado a mucha gente así que si teníais pensado leerlo seguid con la idea. Esta es mi opinión y es algo muy personal, es decir, que no tiene por qué ser ninguna verdad universal ni tiene que ser lo que os pase a vosotros si leéis este libro. Peeeero es mi experiencia con él...

En historia om en flicka på ett internat som övergavs av sin mammans hon var elva, och nu söker svar på existensiella frågor om trygghet, tilltro och identitet. Parallellt handlar det om fem vänner, i en annan tid, och hur deras liv vävs in i Taylors.Konstig på många vis. Hade först svårt att komma in i röran, men plötsligt ville jag bara läsa vidare. Men kunde aldrig släppa att det är en konstig historia och hade svårt att bestämma om jag tyckte om den eller inte.
This may be the most depressing book I’ve ever read.
Ehh it was ok

It was a good book. I think I would have enjoyed it more if it weren't for the book discussions we did about this book in school. The teacher kind of gave it away early on and you had no space to form your own ideas about what would happen or how it all would turn out. There were some elements of surprise but mostly I think it was quite cliché and predictable. It was good, but not a challenging plot to figure out.

Emo! Melodrama! Reviews for this book are very mixed, from "oh-my-gawd-I-loved-it!" to "omg-I-hated-it!". I can't say I hated it but I didn't like it. For about half of the book -I am lying, for the WHOLE book- I was 🤔 with the whole war game thing. What was the purpose of that game?? I thought I was reading a dystopian book... it didn't make any sense.Taylor, the MC, was either crying or being angry.. the whole book. Her love interest was another emo. Was there any happiness for those people? Hannah's story was MEH... only around the end we know who is who, so because it didn't interest me, when I was reading, Webb had the same face as Fitz and Jude, and Narnie and Tate were the same girl, so I had zero attach to these characters.Nope, i didn't like this book. Made me think the whole time "what is the point of this story?"

Voiam mai mult, mai multa chimie, mai mult mister. Am primit doar nisip în ochi. Chestii pe care nu le-am inteles nici la sfarsit. Ce era cu războiul ala?? Inteleg luptele de liceu între diverse bisericuțe, dar asta s-a vrut a fi dus la extrem și a iesit un kkt amestecat.M-a amenințat cu traume și n-am simțit nimic. Relatia mamă-fiică, fiasco total. Da. Te-a abandonat. Da. O urasti. Da. O cauti ca un câine turbat. Si ce?? "Și viața merge mai departe", dar niciodata nu e asa usor.Prost fragmentată, prost aranjată. Ar fi trebuit să-mi curgă mucii suroaie, dar n-am simțit nimic. Poate un pic de mila din loc în loc.A avut o parte bună. Unde a existat și chimie. Jude și Hannah. Atât. In rest, s-a încercat mult și nu a iesit nimic. Păcat de idee.Si care-i treaba cu Fitz ăsta??? Cred ca mi-a scăpat ceva totuși!

Had a really hard time with this one... Maybe I wasn't focused enough, but there were too many names and people who weren't explained enough to me so I really didn't understand a lot of it. I appreciated the story as a whole, as well as the ending, but I just thought it was unnecessarily confusing. And not like in a good mystery-type confusion, but just in a "I don't understand anything"-kind of way. Meh.
Too angsty for me

I'm sorry, but I don't understand the sobbing 5-star reviews. First of all: The beginning. I mean, like, the first 150 pages. What even was that? I didn't understand a single thing that was going on and I couldn't keep up with any of the characters. The first time I picked this up I spent about a week getting to page 156 and then couldn't drag myself through it any longer. This time I went in hard and powered through the entire book in two days (even though I very much didn't understand why the entire first half). It does get noticeably better in the second half. But not as much as I hoped. Second of all: The characters weren't that well developed. At least I didn't feel I got to know Raffy or Jessa or what-was-that-person's-name? at all. Third of all: Unnecessary relationship between plain YA-protagonist and boring love interest. Don't come for me please.Forth of all: I still don't completely understand how Taylor figured everything out. (view spoiler)[Like how did she know Hannah was Narnie, and how did she find out that Fitz shot Webb? (hide spoiler)] This was probably explained and I just didn't read closely enough. So yeah. Great that y'all loved it but this was not for me.

This book was told in a fragmented way that I felt was not necessary to the story. Nor was Hannah and Jude keeping Taylor’s past a secret from her. A lot of unnecessary mystery and secret keeping that was not believable to me. I also just didn’t connect with the characters like it appears many readers did. 🤷‍♀️
Confusing. Not relatable. Disjointed- “What do you want from me?" he asks. What I want from every person in my life, I want to tell him. More.”
very slow start and took a long time to get into. the 2nd half of the book was much better.
DNF
I'm sure this is a great book, but it just wasn't for me. I couldn't connect with the characters well or understood what was going in the story at all. I ended up not finishing the book.

My criticisms of this book are definitely a mixture of Me problems and Book problems — things I personally didn't like and things that I think are genuinely not good about the book. I was going to try to split them out but I'm not sure how helpful that would be, so I'll just run through them all here.-The book doesn't give you a lot of clues to orient yourself, so it's hard to follow at first. I don't necessarily mind this in a book — sometimes it's fun to try to piece things together — but it's a solid third of the way through the book before you have any kind of clue WTF is going on. That was far too long for me and kept me from feeling connected to the main character because I couldn't understand her motives for a lot of what she did, much of which was being terrible to other people.-Once the pieces did start falling into place, I found it to be disappointingly predictable. I figured out who the Brigadier was chapters before Taylor did. If it was supposed to be a mystery, it didn't play out like one — it was more like everything was a confusing jumble, so I didn't even know what I was looking at, and then suddenly it all came into focus and I was just waiting for Taylor to catch up.-The writing felt much more like telling than showing. It was very choppy, a lot of "This happened and then this happened and then this person said this." This meant that the romance felt underdeveloped and I had no real reason to root for them to get together or stay together, and the fact that they were either jumping each other or screaming at each other felt disconnected to any actual passion.-Also, Jonah is kind of a terrible person at the opening of the book, and he never really redeems himself. It's more like a combination of Taylor remembering him at his most vulnerable + he behaves like a halfway-decent person for a while. The characters are constantly throwing one-liners at each other, so we don't see who they are as individuals. At one point we're told something like, "Jonah said some witty things to the girls," which just felt like lazy writing to me — tell us what the witty things were, and maybe we'll get some sense of his personality?-The underdeveloped writing also extended to plotting. One example: Taylor's bike gets stolen. Then there's a chapter where she's riding her bike into enemy territory. Then later her bike turns up again. We get no explanation — Was this a flashback? Did she borrow someone else's bike? No idea. Another example: The kids all get in the car together and they're driving and driving and Taylor is settling into the back seat and watching the colors go by the window, until she sees something and makes them all stop. When they get back in the car, the driver says, "Where should we go?" and they have a whole discussion about it and then start driving again. There's no reason that conversation couldn't have happened before they started driving initially, and it's unclear where exactly they were planning to drive to in the first place before they screeched to a halt and then had a conversation about it. This contributed to the feeling of being lost while reading, and it didn't feel intentional, just sloppy.-I am not a fan of magical realism, so all the pieces with the boy in the tree in Taylor's dream and how she named herself before she was born were a little eye-roll-y to me.I actually really liked the idea behind the book and I think I would have genuinely liked the book a lot had it been executed better. There's a sweet message about found family and laying aside differences and how we can come to terms with the past and move forward. And the interweaving of Hannah's book, as Taylor's reading it out of order, was a clever device. It was just unfortunate that we're told at the very beginning that Taylor's story opens "twenty-two years later" than the start of Hannah's story, because otherwise we, like Taylor, might think it was fictional until the coincidences with real life start happening.So, on the whole, I didn't hate the book, and I can understand why people like it (I was even tearing up a little bit at the end), but in general it was hard to get through and not enjoyable for me personally.
This was just way too confusing.
Confusing.I don't even know what to say.

It seems that I am in the minority for not loving this book. There was a poetic and haunting quality to it, but I could not relate to the characters or their pain as written and I was utterly confused for the first half of the book. The story is full of darkness and dysfunction, powerful in its way. Not my cup of tea, though.

Wow. I must have really missed something here. I found it boring, convoluted and neither relatable or believable. I thought it was quite an unrealistic portrayal of trauma and it did nothing for me emotionally. For example, her mother is a “drug addict” who abandoned her daughter. There’s no nuance- I gather we’re supposed to believe all drug addicts are the same so there’s no need to go into any detail of her mother’s addiction or personality, because “Addict due to past trauma” is her whole identity. All the interesting emotions were brushed over in a shallow way and there was little depth or complexity.
Me costó adentrarme en la historia porque al principio todo era muy confuso.Toma un matiz un poco interesante a medida pasan las páginas pero no lo suficiente para que me pareciera una buena lectura.

It’s taken me a long time to write this review. I love many things about this book but am overwhelmed by discomfort. Anger even. One of the important failings is the head space of a child without parents. It wasn’t realistic to me. I know this is a hugely unpopular view and the majority of readers love this book but I found the soppiness upsetting. Unrealistic. Dismissive of the true experiences of voiceless children. It was a book about some kids without parents that is opaque and unrealistic in its approach and I feel that it’s unfair and let’s down and is a disservice to the true to life experiences of such kids - books are written about this world so rarely. What a missed opportunity! At least show SOME aspects of reality. We were allowed to feel sorry for rejected characters (druggies on the street) but no real engagement was achieved. Instead the message was to reject and give up on them. The lucky and loved remained the entitled. So... In the end I found this book offensive. I know it’s safe and easily consumable but it’s not real. It’s fiction to the true sense and probably easier for conservative readers. A safer read than reality might serve up.

Actually abandoned this one after 100 pages or so. It was good -- had some mystery to it that kept me going for a while to see if I could figure out what was happening -- but ultimately, since my discretionary reading time is precious these days, it didn't seem worth it.

I found this book underwhelming after all the praise I read about it. The book goes on and on for ages with nothing in particular happening. It has two storylines running side by side. That of Taylor Markham who is abandoned by her mother Tate at a 7/11 after Tate phoned her paternal aunt, Hannah to pick her up. And another one running about 22 years earlier which through the course of the book we realise is about Hannah and Taylor’s parents and their friends. I had a problem with this book on the issue of the territory wars. I found it hard to imagine these “wars” and even harder to imagine any teenagers to refer to an ages old notebook containing the regulations on which these wars were said to be waged without wanting to make any amendments themselves. In the end the wars were practically inconsequential to the storyline anyway so the author could have left them out. Ridiculous also is how Hannah never tells Taylor that she is her aunt and her father’s sister, and also that she always kept Taylor at arm’s length. The pathetic explanation that Tate told her not to mother her because she already had a mother really ruins it. I mean what would you do, respect the wishes of a junkie who can’t even respect her own child or show some love to a poor abandoned eleven-year-old? Actually it seems that whilst Taylor longed to find out about her past, all the adults around seemed to conspire to keep her in the dark.

Read for The YA Room's Throwback Bingo Challenge!Challenge Square: Aussie AuthorTHIS IS THE FINAL BOOK I READ IN THE YEAR OF 2018!!! XDAfter feeling very excited to dive into Melina's novels, On The Jellicoe Road turned into a confusing and at times, slow-going mystery/thriller novel that didn't fully capture my interest. In a boarding school environment, the main character Taylor is having to deal with the ghosts of her past, as well as staying secure and happy in the present day. Things take a turn when her guardian suddenly leaves her, after Taylor's own birth mother left her when she was eleven. My overall thoughts are still quite conflicting, so this review may be updated at a later stage. For now though, this wasn't for me!
